Double check the use of cf here (and I suspect in most cases where it is used): in English academic writing it is not common to use 'cf.' when you quote someone. 'Cf.' means 'compare' and is usually used to introduce citations that provide counterarguments (see https://writingcenter.unc.edu/tips-and-tools/latin-terms-and-abbreviations/) The two uses on this page may lead to misunderstandings in the author's argument.

(I made the same comment to Bonami & Crysmann above)  See Bień 1991, p. 16  An earlier introduction of the term ('fleksem'), perhaps with the same denotation ('a morphosyntactically homogeneous set of forms belonging to the same lexeme'). See also Bień & Saloni (1982), where the term is not used, but the idea is already there. This notion of flexeme is used for morphosyntactic annotation of Polish corpora (IPI PAN, NKJP), see Przepiórkowski & Woliński 2003.  Bień, Janusz S. (1991) Koncepcja słownikowej informacji morfologicznej i jej komputerowej weryfikacji. Rozprawy Uniwersytetu Warszawskiego / Dissertationes Univesitatis Varsoviensis - ISSN 0509-7177 (383). Wydawnictwa Uniwersytetu Warszawskiego, Warszawa. ISBN 83-230-0390-4 URL http://bc.klf.uw.edu.pl/12/  Bień, Janusz S. and Saloni, Zygmunt (1982) Pojęcie wyrazu morfologicznego i jego zastosowanie do opisu fleksji polskiej (wersja wstępna). Prace Filologiczne, XXXI. pp. 31-45. ISSN 0138-0567 URL http://bc.klf.uw.edu.pl/63/  Przepiórkowski, A. and Woliński, M. (2003). A flexemic tagset for Polish. In Erjavec, T., editor, MorphSlav ’03 – Proceedings of the 2003 EACL Workshop on Morphological Processing of Slavic Languages, pages 33–40, Budapest, Hungary. Association for Computational Lingu- istics. URL https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1613200.1613205
